name: Iowa Capital Dispatch
title: ‘Mom-arooski’ highlights backyard Turkey Day game
description: CEDAR RAPIDS — College and pro football teams have had a trick play called the Fumblerooski. The Kinney family invented a play I call the “Mom-arooski.” It happened at a backyard Thanksgiving Day touch football game in my sister’s backyard in Cedar Rapids 24 years ago. We were playing “boys vs. girls.” Of course, we […]
text:
(Photo illustration by Patrick Kinney)










The greatest accomplishment is not in never falling, but in rising again after you fall.


– Vince Lombardi


CEDAR RAPIDS — College and pro football teams have had a trick play called the Fumblerooski. The Kinney family invented a play I call the “Mom-arooski.”
It happened at a backyard Thanksgiving Day touch football game in my sister’s backyard in Cedar Rapids 24 years ago.
We were playing “boys vs. girls.” Of course, we boys thought we had the upper hand.
Nope. Dumb as a box of rocks.
On the girls’ opening play, Mom, who was celebrating her 79th birthday that day, crumpled to the ground upon the snap of the ball. We boys all rushed to Mom’s aid, fearing a twisted ankle or worse.
While we were all gathered around Mom, my sister handed off to my daughter Hannah, who was 9 then, and the little sweetie gleefully ran for a touchdown!
Mom was fine. My sister had dialed up a masterpiece, perfectly executed by Mom and Hannah.
I can hear deep-voiced John Facenda, narrator of NFL Films: “A play as devastatingly effective as a Jerry Kramer block on the frozen tundra of Lambeau Field.”
That’s one of my happiest Thanksgiving memories. May you cherish yours and hopefully make some new ones.
Happy Thanksgiving.



Patrick Kinney’s blog, View from the Cedar Valley, is on Substack. This column is republished  through the Iowa Writers’ Collaborative.
Editor’s note: Please consider subscribing to the collaborative and the authors’ blogs to support their work.

name: Idaho Capital Sun
title: How a day at the Y reminded me we can’t forget our Idaho neighbors
description: I am walking through the parking lot of an Idaho YMCA on a cold, dark, Monday morning when I hear the terrified scream of a small child. In the open hatch of a truck parked close to the entrance, I see a little face, eyes wide and tearful, peaking out beneath thick blankets.  I say […]
text:
(Photo by Getty Images)I am walking through the parking lot of an Idaho YMCA on a cold, dark, Monday morning when I hear the terrified scream of a small child. In the open hatch of a truck parked close to the entrance, I see a little face, eyes wide and tearful, peaking out beneath thick blankets. 
I say hello and ask him if he is alone, yes, if he is scared, yes, if he wants to come inside, yes. He puts on a thick Spiderman poncho, and I carry him in. 
The spirited employee who is there every morning lets us come behind the check-in counter. I sit the boy down on a tall chair and take a seat next to him. She calls the police. I realize what is about to happen and warn the boy, the police are going to come, they are going to ask you questions, you are not in trouble, it’s OK to be afraid, it’s OK to ask for help, OK? His eyes are big as he glances toward the door.  
While we wait, I ask him questions: his name, his Halloween costume, his favorite trick-or-treat candy. Where is your mother? Are you hungry? The Y employee pulls a Goldfish snack bag from her own lunch when he says he likes cheese and crackers. 
He tells me his mother is in jail, and it reminds me of stories I’ve heard about the disparate sentencing for women here and how Idaho has the highest incarceration rate of women in the United States, by a lot.  
The police arrive, and they ask the boy questions; he doesn’t answer them but after they turn away he asks me where their guns are. I have trouble understanding him so he makes the signal for a gun with his pointer finger and thumb and points to their belts. 
Five EMTs arrive, all, it seems, sporting mustaches, to check for cold exposure. They are friendly, are able to get a couple answers out of him and leave without any concerns. 
Dad comes out and looks shocked but sober and calm. I can hear some of the questions the officers are asking: Where do you work? What were you thinking? Where do you park your car to sleep? It’s illegal to sleep in your car in Idaho in cities with populations over 100,000 so I gather they are building their case. 
The father says he is employed in the trades, an essential profession, and that his son goes to day care. I hear him tell the officer that he thought if his son woke up and got afraid he could just come inside. It’s a big miscalculation, born more from a lack of understanding of the socio-emotional needs of a child that age than from some intentional harm or simple neglect. 
The boy says he wants to go to his dad so we let him down from the tall chair and he gives his dad a big punch in the leg, as if to say, how dare you leave me. I say hello to the dad and goodbye to the boy and try to get some exercise before work, but I am quickly called back to the front desk to give a statement. 
The officer, a new one, asks me some basic questions. I repeat the story. She layers my answers with her own judgments, judgements I wouldn’t apply in this situation. 
Any questions for me, she asks. I ask if they are connecting the father with services. Oh we will connect him with services; he’ll be hearing from Heath and Welfare, she says in a lofty tone. 
The process is a total scene, so public, and so shameful. If I were that father, I’d find it hard to show my face there again. I myself have trouble returning the next day. 
Visceral memories of my own single mother, our houseless struggles, being left alone, terrified, and finally, the loss of her, all come flooding back. 
I have no recourse. I have no way of knowing what happened next, no way of offering the support I know he needs and that I would freely give. I am prevented from caring any further by a system that steps in instead. I am forced to walk away and encouraged to forget. 
But I cannot forget. 
We cannot forget that child’s face, not in the richest country in the world, while our government wastes money on ballrooms and bailouts, parties and private jets. Not while they rig it so the rich get richer while that little boy sleeps in the back of a truck with his mother in jail. I will never forget that father’s face, holding his son’s hand while the whole world bears down.

title: An unforgettable Thanksgiving with Tennessee’s Angry Grandmother
description: My father and mother were born in the 1920’s, grew up during the Depression and World War II, and November and December were not very different for them than the other 10 months of the year. text:
A mother-in-law tries to accommodate her vegetarian, politically opposite son-in-law one Thanksgiving, with mixed results. My father and mother were born in the 1920’s, grew up during the Depression and World War II, and November and December were not very different for them than the other 10 months of the year. Thanksgiving and Christmas days were quiet and simple. 
But not for their children: It was important to my parents to create memories for us and their grandchildren and what better way to do that than to start the holiday season with an unforgettable Thanksgiving lunch.  Food was always a big part of any special occasion that involved my   m demothe
My husband Larry’s first Thanksgiving meal as an official part of my family came in 1992. My family —  the Terrys — were East Tennessee Lincoln Republicans.  Even though he is a yellow dog Democrat, Larry had been warmly accepted by my family — or so he thought. 
Mother always started her Christmas decorating the day after Halloween. Every wall, staircase, table and corner in her home was covered with Christmas decorations and they stayed up at least until Jan. 2.  Starting at Thanksgiving, my sisters and I were expected to wear our best holiday motif sweaters and style our hair for the family pictures that would surely be taken.
Mother set the time that we would eat and on Thanksgiving morning, as soon as we arrived, we went to work. My daddy had an annual ritual of telling my sisters and me that it might be Mother’s last holiday season because she worked too hard. Then Daddy would worry which of his four daughters and their families were going to be late and whether the time of our arrival would impact the time we ate.



				My mother, a Republican, professed to like my new husband, a Democrat. But the food she served him made us all question her intentions.			


My sisters and I knew exactly what was involved in Mother’s “memory creating holiday” meal. My mother inherited her mother’s table and normally my parents had enough room around it for four to six people. But not for family gatherings! There were several heavy big wooden leaves that had to be installed to seat up to 20 people and the leaves had to be locked in to avoid accidents.  Our husbands offered to help, which we accepted for only the heavy lifting, and we had to collect chairs from all over the house and make sure they were sturdy. A chair collapsing during a big meal was funny but could be unhealthy. We then asked the men to leave so the sisters could privately share our news — or call it gossip if you must. 
The tablecloth had to hang correctly and at one time Mother’s table looked like something out of “Downton Abby” with her best china, polished sterling silver and cloth napkins. 
When it was just the two of them, Mother rarely cooked for Daddy. There was a friendly meat-and-three restaurant in their neighborhood, and eating there at least once a day —not necessarily together  —was a way for Daddy and Mother to socialize with the community and keep up with what was going on. 
This informal eatery had a catering service, and Mother decided to order her Thanksgiving meal from them. She picked up her order and put the containers of food in the trunk of her car, drove the short distance home and brought the food into her kitchen. She got up early on Thanksgiving morning to warm the food and to transfer most of it to her dishes. 
My husband, Larry Woods, was already a vegetarian when we married, and this caused much angst in our family. They thought he would starve without meat and that it would be okay to serve vegetables that had been cooked with pork, chicken or beef.  I suggested Mother add a dish of macaroni and cheese for Larry because what could go wrong?  Everyone loves macaroni and cheese. 
When we finally sat down to eat Daddy always said a few words before offering grace. Mother, in turn, always worried the food was getting cold while Daddy was praising Mother for her efforts and the Lord for our bounty. We kept our heads bowed and sometimes glanced and smiled at each other wondering how long this would go on before we could finally eat. 
Passing all the food was a production. which according to Mother — and manners expert Emily Post — was to the right. We all talked at the same time and tried not to drop the heavy serving pieces as we passed around the food. We had been raised to put a small portion of every dish on our plate, which did not apply to the vegetarian at the table. 
As we ate, I noticed the mac and cheese had a strange taste to it and that Larry was stirring and playing with his mac and cheese instead of eating it and served himself a mound of bread each time the silver breadbasket was passed. 
Finally, we cleared the table and began preparing dessert. When my sisters and I were alone in the kitchen, I asked them if they noticed anything weird about the mac and cheese, and they all said it tasted terrible. One of us asked Mother if she had tasted it. She reminded us that she did not care for mac and cheese but there could have been a problem with the kerosene she kept in her car spilling in her trunk and “just perhaps” some of that kerosene spilled onto the mac and cheese. Mother said she was not going to throw away good money spent on food just because of a little kerosene. We did not know whether to laugh hysterically or be horrified. 
The next day Larry was on “The Roundtable,” a Nashville talk radio program that featured politicos discussing current events. Live and on the air, he said that his new mother-in-law had tried to kill him at his first Thanksgiving meal because his candidate, and not hers, had just won the 1992 Presidential election. Mother was listening, she called me immediately and said to tell Larry she was going to kill him and just tell God he died. 
The mac and cheese with kerosene became part of our family history. Vegetarian dishes are always viewed with suspicion, especially during an election year, and we still do not know why the kerosene was in Mother’s trunk, but Larry took great joy for many years by sharing the story of how his mother-in-law tried to kill him that Thanksgiving Day.
